Award.AwardTitle: CC*IIE Networking Infrastructure: Enabling and Improving Data-Driven Research at Texas State University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Data are now woven into every sector and function in our society. Texas State researchers are pioneering in solving some of the most pressing challenges using big data in the fields of Biochemistry, Biology, Geography, Computer Science, Finance and Economics, Mathematics, and Information Systems. Nonetheless, the current Texas State cyberinfrastructure and connectivity capacity present obstacles to the research projects involving big data and the collaborations among multiple institutions sharing massive amounts of data.

This project develops a high-speed campus network infrastructure to enable and improve data-driven research at Texas State. It enables immediate 10Gb capability and 100Gb in the future, and creates a Science DMZ on the campus network dedicated to research data to allow researchers to exchange large datasets with their peers over the network at a much faster speed. The infrastructure enhances and better facilitates big data research across a wide range of disciplines at Texas State with notable societal benefits, enables all other Texas State University System member institutions to establish similar environments to accommodate their research and education needs, advances the integration of research and education, promotes cross-institutional collaborations, and will significantly enhance the current big data research and teaching capabilities at Texas State and beyond.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project are to: 1) Acquire hardware necessary for improved services to campus and establishing of Science DMZ and dedicated research network pathway. 2) Install hardware and establish dedicated pathway. 3) Establish and deploy Science DMZ hardware. And 4) Support and assist research(ers) utilization of new pathway and Science DMZ

At the end of this project, all the documented hardware has been acquired from vendors. All routers have been deployed and are in production. 10Gb services have been acquired and deployed from network/ISP providers. Services improvement from Nx1Gb services to Nx10Gb services has met and exceeded demand for bandwidth from the institution. Research and non-research demand for connectivity is being met. Dedicated research pathway has been established with improved services at 10Gb. This improvement allows for improved throughput for scientific purposes. DTN and perfSonar (Science DMZ) nodes are racked and powered. Globus information is available for the DTN. We have been able to achieve up to 7.8Gbps to other perfSONAR nodes in recent tests. We have deployed IPv6. We have purchased an additional 10Gb circuit and was able to bring it into service over the summer of 2017. We have supported and assisted researchers to utilize the new pathway and Science DMZ. We have seen network improvement with some of our researchers, and have been able to assist several researchers not mentioned in our proposal as an added benefit.

This project has allowed us to upgrade the Texas State network infrastructure at the Texas State University System (TSUS) Network level and the TXSTATE Campus Network level. The new network provides the eight Texas State member institutions including Texas State, Sam Houston State University, Lamar University, Lamar Institute of Technology, Lamar State College Port Arthur, Lamar State College-Orange, Sul Ross State University, and Sul Ross State University Rio Grande College with direct and indirect network connections to Internet2, GENI, ESNet, SETG and other university system networks across domestic and international research communities. This developed fast-speed network infrastructure provides necessary capabilities for the researchers to exchange large amount of data with their collaborators and download massive data from websites so as to promote intra- and inter-university collaborations.
